title: The Mystery Memo
setting: Greenfield Biotech, executive floor, Tuesday 11 AM
premise: A confidential memo about upcoming layoffs was leaked to the press. The memo was emailed only to four people Monday evening, and the news article was published Tuesday at 8 AM.

suspects.name: Sandra Liu
suspects.motive: Opposes the layoffs and has been fighting to save positions in her department
suspects.alibi: I read the memo at 6 PM Monday and went home. I turned off my work phone for the night. I found out about the leak Tuesday when I arrived at 8:30 AM.

suspects.name: Roger Finch
suspects.motive: Has been in contact with a rival firm and wants to destabilize leadership
suspects.alibi: I was at a board dinner Monday from 7 PM to 10 PM at The Grand Hotel. Eight board members can confirm I was there. I went straight home after.

suspects.name: Monica Page
suspects.motive: Believes transparency about layoffs is ethically required
suspects.alibi: I reviewed the memo Monday at 5:30 PM and left by 6 PM. I spent the evening at home reviewing case files. My home alarm system confirms I was home by 6:30.

suspects.name: Alan Chu
suspects.motive: His position is among those being eliminated in the layoff plan
suspects.alibi: I sent the memo to all four recipients at 5 PM Monday as instructed by the CEO. After that I filed it and left the office at 5:15 PM. I didn't read the memo's contents.

clues.title: Reporter's Source Clue
clues.content: The newspaper reporter confirms the leak came via a personal email sent at 10:47 PM Monday night. The source included a screenshot of the memo, not a forwarded copy.

clues.title: Home Network Evidence
clues.content: IT traced the screenshot metadata showing it was taken on a phone at 6:02 PM Monday. The phone's Wi-Fi was connected to Greenfield's office network at that time.

clues.title: Alan's Email Access
clues.content: Alan claims he didn't read the memo's contents. But the screenshot metadata matches his phone model, and the email server log shows he opened the memo attachment at 5:58 PM â€” 43 minutes after he claims to have left at 5:15 PM.

hints.text: Focus on what time each suspect claims to have left the office and whether that matches the digital evidence.
If someone says they never read the memo, does the email server log agree with that claim?
